text: Hi friends! I’m looking for feedback on this drafted-fake PR release trying to discover Product-Market-Fit. Would deeply appreciate your insights and feedback. <https://docs.google.com/document/d/1sIlJAE01Gbu06FnhLSldK4rZuFKX6Njg40JtHWOQ6aM/edit>
Feel free to DM me if you would like questions. Or share them in this thread. Thank you!
Sorry, but what "PMF" means? Clicking on the link I have guessed that PR = Press Release, but can't figure about PMF... :wink:
Product-Market-Fit. I’ll update that :thumbsup:
Thanks Gabe! :slightly_smiling_face: good feedback, gonna make some changes here soon along those lines.
The TLDR was my favorite part. I have always wanted "Zapier but code" and "JSFiddle for backends" so any way you can explain why Storyscript is "that" would be compelling to me
Thanks <@U5TCAFTD3> :thumbsup:

Hi Steve, I read the entire docs and I'm still confused about what you do. I also clicked around on your website which seems to contradict the docs. The docs says no installation because it is a barrier, on the website I see docs how to install it. The doc starts with one line of code, but I only see multi-line examples. The doc reads more like a business plan than something aimed at users. You can't prove PMF by talking to investors.

Hi all, I plan to share a blog post on Hacker News and wanted to gather some feedback if it is any interesting and if one can follow it - or if not, why not? Would really appreciate any feedback!
<http://feedback.boomla.com/blog/a-filesystem-to-replace-your-cms>

attachments.title: A filesystem to replace your CMS
attachments.fallback: Boomla: A filesystem to replace your CMS

text: Interesting! This reminds me a lot of how Zope works (or used to work, back when I worked with it, over a decade ago.) The backing storage was basically a hierarchical db, stored on disk as a btree of pickled python objects.
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zope_Object_Database>

attachments.title: Zope Object Database
attachments.text:
The Zope Object Database (ZODB) is an object-oriented database for transparently and persistently storing Python objects. It is included as part of the Zope web application server, but can also be used independently of Zope.
Features of the ZODB include: transactions, history/undo, transparently pluggable storage, built-in caching, multiversion concurrency control (MVCC), and scalability across a network (using ZEO).

text: So is the way the CMS features work just editing files on the filesystem?
Because that feels more like a static site generator than a CMS to me. I think I'm missing something.
Oh I see (looking at the developer tutorial). You create files through the web interface.

Allowing users to add code/functionality through the web interface was a feature of Zope as well, early on, but was quickly abandoned, when it was found it was impossible to sandbox. Hopefully your js engine does a better job of that :slightly_smiling_face:
Hey Eric thanks for the info! Never heard of Zope before. I'll check it out! Funnily, my nickname is Zupa. xD
Yeah sandboxing is solved in Boomla
What is a file's type property? Are you assuming a specific file system?
<@UCUSW7WVD> yes, this only works with the Boomla filesystem. Effectively there is a platform built around this filesystem, and the 2 only work together.
apparently that's not obvious, so I should emphasize?
Huh, your own file system. Does/will the binary distribution include it?
<@UCUSW7WVD> sure

Hmm, it doesn't seem optional, right?

What OS does your file system run on?
I know first it sounds crazy, but I have not heard a single complaint for it.
No complaints. Yet :slightly_smiling_face: Just trying to understand what it is.

No it's not optional. It's not a posix filesystem so it's not that you could run it with anything else. I wrote a new kernel around it. So it's basically a new OS. Not that you could boot into it, it runs on an existing OS, giving you a new application platform on top.
<@UP448V1PB> you can use it as a static site generator if you want, but you can also edit it via the frontend and have dynamic applications too

The first versions of the platform were prototyped in PHP, but I abandoned PHP because there was no way to sandbox it. It seems that ZODB only works with python. That sounds like a design mistake to me. Boomla already works with 2 languages, JS and Go, although Go is limited to kernel space (it is written in Go..), but at least there is a guarantee that the kernel APIs are properly in place.

Ok I think I understand a bit now. It seems confusing to call it a file system if I can't see the files on my computer outside of your application. 'File system' is also a technical detail that your target audience may not understand or care about.

I'd suggest not partitioning your program from your storage layer initially. Instead focus on what your application enables that would be hard with a database.

> It seems confusing to call it a file system if I can't see the files on my computer outside of your application.

Interesting comment. I guess I'm technically correct (if you write a new OS, and you can't access its filesystem from another OS, it's still a filesystem) but if it gives you the wrong idea it is still wrong. Good point, thank you.

Rereading the title, it was not obvious that "a filesystem" was what was new here. Why did you build a whole new file system for a CMS? Do you plan other applications using it? Do you plan to make it a complete bootable OS?

I want to build a cloud based OS that is super easy to program. The CMS part aims to be the "killer app". There are other kinds of small apps built on top of it. I don't think it needs to be bootable. It could be, but I don't see the benefits.
Interesting!
What platform does it require underneath?
Thanks a lot, I'll try to clarify it along your input.
It runs on Linux, OS X, Windows
For context on some of my questions, I've been packaging up programs with a third party OS that can be imaged on cloud servers. <https://github.com/akkartik/mu>

It's a single binary. I found it pretty cool to put all binaries on a pendrive, initiate a workspace on it and take it with me. Then I can run the platform anywhere I sit down. But then again, having it on a server is easier...
What do you use to make it cross-platform? Did you write your own abstractions?
Yes I just saw your earlier <#CCL5VVBAN|feedback> thread and was blown away by the 40k machine code you wrote. =O
It's written in Go so the cross-compilation is almost too easy.
Oh ok, sorry for the advertising. Just trying to compare and contrast approaches.
What about the UI layer? Do you use native widgets?
Ah no problem. I wanted to give you feedback to but I realized I'm short of knowledge there
The only UI is the browser. (Okay there is a cli too.)
It seems freekin crazy how much effort you put into Mu. How long did you work on it?
So you write html/css/js?
Does the CLI just print lines? Or does it also move the cursor and use colors and so on? That would require cross-platform support?
& markdown, yes
no, it just prints :slightly_smiling_face:
:+1::skin-tone-3: Got it. Interesting design choices.
How do you implement the file system? Does it get saved to a single file on the host or something like that?
Exactly. I've tried multiple approaches but the single file approach performed best.
Btw, the filesystem is basically just an API. The rest is an implementation detail.
Well you probably new this. :stuck_out_tongue:
Yeah. In my mind I think of this approach as the "file system like API".
Do you have any safeguards if the device suddenly loses power? Or would you lose some mutations that were not yet persisted?

<@UCUSW7WVD> Sorry if you answered this already, but you are looking for feedback anyway, so here it goes. You define Mu as a "computing stack". That's the only definition you give on <http://futureofautomation.wikidot.com/mu> , and I may not be your target audience, but I honestly don't know what that means.

How do you handle interface changes? That's an interesting topic. I try to keep them immutable in my project, and always introduce new VM instead of changing old interfaces, for example. Then phase the old one out if it's not used any more. Of course, it's not always possible, but works most of the time. It also helps me move faster by not worrying much about breaking things.
The disk is append only, all data is stored in merkle trees. If there is a power loss, and the changes are not fully written to disk, the latest valid snapshot will be used.
Most interesting. So it's versioned! Does the file system keep growing?

There is the common issue that the response may be sent before the data is persisted. This is not solved yet (just like in most production systems), but I plan to cover this once it runs on a distributed cluster.
Yes the filesystem keeps growing. I have optimized the shit out of it, and you know what, GC is not implemented yet, and I don't even plan to implement it for a while. It's just so efficient.

This is cool. This isn't just a file system like API. You have most of a real file system.

I think you need a better killer app. There's just so much more you could do with this.

I mean, every real filesystem is just an API. :slightly_smiling_face: Sure I think it has most of the little details implemented as well. For example, it is check-summed so I can verify the backups that no single bit was damaged. I'm most happy about that, I would literally have a hard time sleeping without disk. The frightening thing is, most mainstream filesystems don't have this.
Well, if you can suggest a better killer app for me, by all means, please do!

Besides a CMS, we have several little apps run on it. For example, a shopping list app we share with my family.
<http://shopping-list.boomla.net/>
Because "users" are a platform-wide thing, if you write an app, you don't need to worry about the user aspect. They can register to your site, you approve it, then it just works.

Oh, btw, I built what I call a Posix Bridge for Boomla. It translates between the Boomla and the Posix filesystem, making it possible for you to use your own tools. There is an SFTP server built into the binary distro that lets one do that. Also, there _was_ FUSE support so that you could mount a Boomla website into a directory. But that was buggy and nobody used it, so I removed it. There is also an import/export capability.
Using that, one can literally open an image on the website, draw on it, and save it back. Lots of fun. :slightly_smiling_face:

Thanks for the comments!

> You define Mu as a "computing stack". That's the only definition you give on <http://futureofautomation.wikidot.com/mu>.. I honestly don't know what that means.

If you haven't already, could you check out the start of the final version at <http://akkartik.name/post/mu-2019-1>, see if that's clearer?

Thanks for the reminder to update my "escalator pitch" :slightly_smiling_face:

> How do you handle interface changes?

Do you mean the ones Mu provides, or the ones under Mu?
those of Mu
sry, the ones it provides :slightly_smiling_face:

I don't have any users yet :smile: so this is still tentative, but the idea is to allow fragmentation of interfaces. Each person's computer should be internally consistent, but different Mu computers may have radical differences, either because their owners modified them or because I changed my mind about something.

Copying software from one instance to another is always assumed to require some manual changes. That's what you have to give up in exchange for avoiding bloat over time.

I have some ideas for tooling to help with this, but like I said it hasn't been a problem yet so they're vaporware.
Oh, how long did I work on it? I think a little over a year for this most recent iteration, including learning x86. Around 5 hours a week on average.

That sounds dangerous to me. The biggest benefit of any platform is the available tooling, libraries, programs. It sounds to me like a guarantee that network effects won't help you. Did you have any thoughts about that?

> a little over a year
Wow you must be 10x faster than I am :smile:
You have over 5k commits... Holy shit. That's over 10 commits _every day_.

I don't care about adoption :slightly_smiling_face:

Mu is chasing longevity. I'll be happy with 200 users by the time I die. But I'd like it to grow past that. Even if it's not called Mu, I want to eventually kill compatibility constraints chasing short term adoption. It's killing for our shared infrastructure heritage.

No, that's what I was trying to indicate by "most recent iteration": the Mu repo is 4 years old, and I had a lot more time in the past.

I have a background in processor architecture and compilers. And I'd tried to wrap my head around x86 several times before it finally clicked last year.
okay, you make me feel a bit better ^^
:slightly_smiling_face: I'm fairly mediocre as a programmer. Just have a better memory than most of what it was like to learn this stuff.

> I don't care about adoption
Okay that's interesting. I can imagine being able to bend it to specific use cases is a selling point. But still, each of them will probably fork off "the main Mu". So that's still the common thread there.

> just have a better memory than most
Haha we are opposites then. I definitely got a 2nd grade memory on the assembly line. :stuck_out_tongue:

Thanks again! Just wanted to reiterate one question in case you missed it:

<https://futureofcoding.slack.com/archives/CCL5VVBAN/p1572024474131600?thread_ts=1570949673.034500&cid=CCL5VVBAN>

If you haven't already, could you check out the start of the final version at <http://akkartik.name/post/mu-2019-1>, see if the meaning of "computing stack" is clearer?

Yes I did miss it. Now you redefined it as:
> everything above the processor and OS kernel
Does that mean I need an OS to run your stuff? When reading on, I would have thought that Mu is something I can put on raw hardware to make it run - basically like an OS, but one that is more like a library than a platform; one that I can bend to my needs.
So, which is it? :slightly_smiling_face:
<@UCUSW7WVD> mentioning to make sure you see it
:+1::skin-tone-3: mu uses a third-party OS. But it's packaged in. So you're right both ways. Let me think about how to make this clearer. Thank you! :bow:
Yeah sorry. Btw, I didn't read the entire page as it was a bit too lengthy.
I guess we are fighting the same problem: how to condense WHAT it is we are working on :slightly_smiling_face:
And it's a common problem here! Designing the future requires breaking a few pigeonholes. And that makes communication harder.
yeah, totally agree
Is Alan Kay in the group? Should be. :slightly_smiling_face:
put the photo example with “prettydocs” at the top
it’s super persuasive and worth a thousand words
IMHO
I think a lot of the document would read much more clearly as a case study

eg: here’s frontend dev bob. he wants to start doing react. he goes to the react website and fiddles with tons of code examples to make sure he gets the concepts. then he downloads a neat little package that does everything for him. here’s alice. she’s a backend developer. she wants to find out about… containers? (hard for me to identify the best example because there’s not a specific story in the docs.) she goes to the docker website and looks at this: [image of documentation] and this: [image of installation instructions]. then she tries to pull x down, but it turns out that y. she works on that for an hour, and then it’s 5pm. time to go home. hopefully she’ll know whether or not to use docker by the end of the week

sorry for the formatting im in the middle of something else but that’s my 5-minute take—hope it’s helpful (and didn’t have time to edit for tone so sorry if I’m coming off as overly critical—I love the mission!)
this looks incredibly cool. cant wait to find time to try it out
